text: FWIW, these video demos are hard for me to interpret and give feedback on, since it's hard for me to remember the context from past videos (since, as you can imagine, there's a lot of other stuff happening in my life in between videos). It would be easier for me to read and respond to a blog post, or to play with an interactive demo. Not sure if that's why the previous video didn't get any feedback, but that's what holds me back.

text: also don't know what approach to take on the post, since I don't know what the reader is expecting, an overview? motivation? feature tour?

elements.text: also don't know what approach to take on the post, since I don't know what the reader is expecting, an overview? motivation? feature tour?

text:
The scary thing is: that's up to you, as the author. You need to be able to figure out what will interest your audience, and make that. The reader will expect what you set up their expectations for.

Same deal with the video. In this case, you set it up as "I added if/then/else to my formula editor" — that doesn't really spark interest. I don't really need to watch a 3 minute video about that, since the title says it all.

I wouldn't suggest making the title more vague. Rather, I'd suggest finding a way to make your video or writing helpful, entertaining, or otherwise enticing to the reader/viewer, and to make that visible from the outside.

One way to do that is to ask for very specific feedback: "I added conditional logic to my expression editor. I'm wondering if it would be better to add something richer, like a Prolog-style solver, but I'm not sure that it'd work well in this interface. How do you think I should proceed?"

Another way to do that is to share something you've discovered: "I added if/then/else logic to my formula editor, and that led me down a rabbit hole where I found a better UI for handling conditional expressions than you normally see in a spreadsheet-like tool. I made a 1-minute video showing how the new UI works."

elements.text:
The scary thing is: that's up to you, as the author. You need to be able to figure out what will interest your audience, and make that. The reader will expect what you set up their expectations for.

Same deal with the video. In this case, you set it up as "I added if/then/else to my formula editor" — that doesn't really spark interest. I don't really need to watch a 3 minute video about that, since the title says it all.

I wouldn't suggest making the title more vague. Rather, I'd suggest finding a way to make your video or writing helpful, entertaining, or otherwise enticing to the reader/viewer, and to make that visible from the outside.

One way to do that is to ask for very specific feedback: "I added conditional logic to my expression editor. I'm wondering if it would be better to add something richer, like a Prolog-style solver, but I'm not sure that it'd work well in this interface. How do you think I should proceed?"

Another way to do that is to share something you've discovered: "I added if/then/else logic to my formula editor, and that led me down a rabbit hole where I found a better UI for handling conditional expressions than you normally see in a spreadsheet-like tool. I made a 1-minute video showing how the new UI works."

text: What is this slack’s opinions on how the “group” feature for visual scripting should function? It’s very similar to functions.

elements.text: What is this slack’s opinions on how the “group” feature for visual scripting should function? It’s very similar to functions.

text: Visual script is another name for flow based programming

elements.text: Visual script is another name for flow based programming

text: There are a lot of different ways this can be implemented. I'm fond of the subpatcher approach in Max/MSP, which allows the "grouped" code to be used as though it were a function, and you can have GUI elements inside the sub-patch show through to the patch that uses it.

elements.text: There are a lot of different ways this can be implemented. I'm fond of the subpatcher approach in Max/MSP, which allows the "grouped" code to be used as though it were a function, and you can have GUI elements inside the sub-patch show through to the patch that uses it.

text: What is the subpatcher approach?

elements.text: What is the subpatcher approach?

text: I don’t understand what I’m seeing.

text: what

elements.text: what

text:
Subpatchers and groups are basically the same thing, from a UI perspective. You select the nodes you want to group together, and then they're bundled up into a new composite node with all the required inputs and outputs.

The difference is how you treat the code inside the new composite node. In most visual languages, if you duplicate a "group", it makes a copy of all the code — if you make changes inside one copy of the group, that doesn't change the other copies of the group. Whereas creating a "subpatcher" in Max, or defining some sort of reusable node or symbol or function in other visual languages with this feature, means that changing the contents of one instance will change all the others — they're all just instances of the same canonical source code.

elements.text:
Subpatchers and groups are basically the same thing, from a UI perspective. You select the nodes you want to group together, and then they're bundled up into a new composite node with all the required inputs and outputs.

The difference is how you treat the code inside the new composite node. In most visual languages, if you duplicate a "group", it makes a copy of all the code — if you make changes inside one copy of the group, that doesn't change the other copies of the group. Whereas creating a "subpatcher" in Max, or defining some sort of reusable node or symbol or function in other visual languages with this feature, means that changing the contents of one instance will change all the others — they're all just instances of the same canonical source code.

text: Here's a blog post where someone talks about how they implemented grouping (they call the operation "compact") in their visual language (unrelated to Max/MSP): <https://blog.duangle.com/2015/01/conspire-programming-environment-for.html>

elements.text: Here's a blog post where someone talks about how they implemented grouping (they call the operation "compact") in their visual language (unrelated to Max/MSP):

text:
The group vs subpatcher distinction is just this:

When you make a new composite node that acts like a function/subroutine (whether you call this a "group", "subpatch", or whatever)... and you use a few copies of that composite node in your system... what happens when you change the composite node's internals? Are all the copies changed, or are they all independent?

I think that any truly great visual language would let you control that in powerful ways.

elements.text:
The group vs subpatcher distinction is just this:

When you make a new composite node that acts like a function/subroutine (whether you call this a "group", "subpatch", or whatever)... and you use a few copies of that composite node in your system... what happens when you change the composite node's internals? Are all the copies changed, or are they all independent?

I think that any truly great visual language would let you control that in powerful ways.

text: Then that's the way subpatchers work in Max/MSP, and not the way grouping typically works (where groups are anonymous and are used just for visual organization, not creating reusable functions).

elements.text: Then that's the way subpatchers work in Max/MSP, and not the way grouping typically works (where groups are anonymous and are used just for visual organization, not creating reusable functions).

text: If you're working on a visual language, I highly, highly recommend getting your hands on a copy of Max/MSP and going through the tutorials. They've put more effort into the GUI than 99% of other visual languages. It's certainly not as good as it could be, but it's the best mainstream visual language in my opinion.

elements.text: If you're working on a visual language, I highly, highly recommend getting your hands on a copy of Max/MSP and going through the tutorials.
